The Chapter on the Causes and Effects of Their Entry, Part 5 of the Treatise says:
Thus, the characteristics of the knowable that are to be entered have been explained. How can their entry, causes, and effects be seen?
It is said that it is due to the six perfections of giving, morality, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom.
How does one enter into consciousness-only through the six perfections?
Moreover, how do the six perfections become the fruits of that entry?

It is said that when this bodhisattva is not attached to wealth and status, does not violate morality, is unmoved by suffering, is not lax in cultivation, and does not engage in the causes of distraction such as these, the mind becomes focused on a single object and is able to discern phenomena in accordance with principle and enter into consciousness-only.
Having entered into consciousness-only by relying on the six perfections, the bodhisattva realizes the perfections that are subsumed by the six kinds of pure superior intention.

Therefore, even if one is separated from the six perfections in one's present practice, by gaining understanding of the holy teachings and by loving, rejoicing, and delighting in all practices, one always constantly and uninterruptedly practices the six perfections with appropriate skillful means, and they are quickly perfected.
The commentary says:
The causes for entering into cognition-only, namely the worldly six perfections during the stage of added effort, will now be explained.

It is said that this bodhisattva is not attached to wealth and status. Because he is not greedy, he is called not attached. Attachment is the opposite of giving, and this is the obstacle to the perfection of giving. The same is true for the following five.

Not violating morality means not breaking the precepts, which is the obstacle to the perfection of morality.ğŸ”½Not being moved by suffering means not being agitated by anger, which is the obstacle to the perfection of patience.
Not being lazy in practice means not being lazy, which is the obstacle to the perfection of vigor.

The mind is concentrated on a single object means that in the causes of distraction that are the counteragents to the perfection of meditative concentration, one is not unmoved, and one holds the mind to be concentrated.
One is then able to discern phenomena in accordance with principle is precisely the perfection of wisdom.

Through these six perfections one enters into consciousness only. Having already entered, one realizes the six kinds of perfections that are included in the pure superior intention and are the excellent fruit.
Therefore, even if one sets aside the actual practice of the perfections, if one always constantly and uninterruptedly cultivates the six perfections, will they quickly be perfected or not?
If one does not perform the practice of the perfection of morality, one should be one who violates the precepts.
This is not so, because one does not make the effort to practice.
If one does not perform the practice of morality, one should have this fault. It is not that one has this fault without making the effort to practice.
Because they spontaneously engage in practice based on their superior understanding of the holy teachings, there is no fault.

Here, those who have attained superior understanding of the holy teachings are those who, although the holy teachings associated with the perfections are extremely profound, are able to believe and understand them.
The attitude of cherishing means to experience the flavor of the virtues of the perfections that one has already attained.
The attitude of rejoicing means to deeply rejoice in the perfections in the life-streams of others in all the worlds of the ten directions, or in the individual life-streams of oneself.
The attitude of delight means to wish in the future that oneself and these [perfections] will always be inseparable and will become more and more excellent.
The treatise says:
Here there are three verses:
Having already perfected the pure dharmas and attained sharp and swift acceptance,
The bodhisattva in the profound and vast teachings of his own vehicle,
Equally awakens to mere conceptualization and attains non-conceptual wisdom,
The mind is joyful and pure.ğŸ”½Previously and in this Dharma stream,
All can see the buddhas,ğŸ”½Understanding that enlightenment is near,
Because it is not difficult to attain.
Based on these three verses, the pure superior intention is shown to have eight aspects: accumulation, endurance, object, attention, antidote, essence, auspicious sign, and benefit.
The verses should be understood to illustrate these in order.
The commentary states:
Herein, the accumulation, endurance, object, attention, antidote, essence, auspicious sign, and benefit of the pure superior intention are clearly explained.

One who has already perfected the pure dharmas refers to one who has already well accumulated the provisions on the ground of resolute practice, and whose pure dharmas are complete. This is called accumulation.

And attaining the swift and sharp forbearance means that among the soft and medium [types of forbearance], only the superior type of forbearance that investigates the Dharma is taken. When this forbearance transforms, it is precisely the forbearance that is able to endure.

The bodhisattva's profound and vast teachings of his own vehicle means that he takes as his object the profound and vast holy teachings of the Mahayana. Its meaning is subtle and fine, called profound, which is precisely the superiority of the non-self of dharmas.
It is associated with majestic virtue and called vast, which are precisely the various samadhis such as the Akasagarbha.
This is called the object.
Only the realization of discrimination means that one realizes that all dharmas only have discrimination. This is called the mental state.
Attaining the non-discriminating cognition is precisely the antidote.
The purity of the mind that seeks and resolves is precisely the essence, because this intention takes faith and desire as its essence.
Both the previous and this Dharma flow and all attain to see the buddhas is precisely the auspicious sign.
The former refers to the stage prior to the purity of intention, and this refers to the Dharma stream in this samÄdhi, which is said to be in the place of samÄdhi within concentration.

Because one sees all buddhas, one knows that enlightenment is near because it is not difficult to attain. This means that because one sees the buddhas, one knows that enlightenment is near. The explanation of this meaning says it is because it is not difficult to attain, which is the benefit.

In this stage, one sees that enlightenment is near, because one attains this superior skillful means. Therefore, it is not difficult to attain, because one has the ability to mature the power of accumulating provisions.
In this way, these three verses comprehensively explain the eight aspects of the pure superior intention.
The treatise states:
For what causes and conditions are there only six numbers of pÄramitÄs?

In order to establish the antidotes to the obstacles that are to be countered, in order to be the basis for realizing the Buddha's teachings, in order to follow and mature all sentient beings, in order to counteract the causes for not setting out, the pÄramitÄs of giving and morality are established.
The cause of not setting out is attachment to wealth and status and attachment to one's family.
In order to counteract the cause of turning back even though one has set out, the perfections of patience and vigor are established.

The cause of turning back is the various sufferings produced by sentient beings' transgressions in the course of cyclic existence, and the fatigue produced by the practice of wholesome activities over a long period of time.
In order to counteract the cause of loss and destruction even though one has set out and does not turn back, the perfections of meditative concentration and wisdom are established.
The cause of loss and destruction is distraction and wrong views.
In this way, the six perfections are established in order to counteract the obstacles that are to be countered.

Moreover, the first four perfections are the causes of non-distraction, and the next perfection is the accomplishment of non-distraction. Relying on this non-distraction, one truly awakens to the true meaning of dharmas and is thus able to realize all Buddha-dharmas.
In this way, the six perfections are established as the basis for realizing all Buddha-dharmas.
Due to the perfection of giving, one is able to properly support sentient beings.
Due to the perfection of morality, one does not harm sentient beings.
Due to the perfection of patience, even if harmed, one is able to endure it.
Due to the perfection of vigor, one is able to assist in their work.
Just by these means of support and benefit, one makes sentient beings capable of being transformed in matters of spiritual maturity.

From this point on, those whose minds are not yet concentrated are caused to attain concentration, and those whose minds are already concentrated are caused to attain liberation. At the time of enlightenment, they attain spiritual maturity.
In this way, in accordance with spiritual maturity, all sentient beings are only established as having six numbers. One should understand this.
The commentary states:
Next, one should reveal the meaning of the number, characteristics, etc. in the final verse. First, based on the establishment of the number, it is said like this.
Establishing the antidotes and the obstacles to be eliminated, there are three reasons why the pÄramitÄs are only six in number, neither more nor less.
First, it is shown that this is in order to establish the antidotes and the obstacles to be eliminated.

In order to counteract the causes for not setting out, the pÄramitÄs of giving and morality are established. Up to in order to counteract the causes for loss and destruction, the pÄramitÄs of concentration and wisdom are established.
The causes for loss and destruction refer to the various kinds of distraction and the erroneous and evil wisdom that leads to inverted grasping.
The various kinds of vulgar and evil wisdom are called erroneous and evil wisdom, like the various non-Buddhist paths which are causes for loss and destruction.
The other phrases are clear and easy to understand as written.
The basis for realizing the Buddha Dharma is the second reason for establishing the number six.
Because this is the cause for all Buddha Dharmas, the number of pÄramitÄs is only six, neither more nor less.
What is the meaning of this?
It means that the first four pÄramitÄs are the causes for non-distraction, able to eliminate the distracted obstacles.
The perfection of meditation is the accomplishment of non-distraction, because it causes non-distraction to be perfected.
Relying on this perfection of meditation, one truly awakens to the true meaning of all dharmas, because one is able to know all objects of cognition in a perfect way.
The dharmas of buddhas refer to the ten powers and so forth.
Attainment means accomplishment.
The third reason for establishing the number six is that they bring sentient beings to maturity in a corresponding way.
By means of the perfection of giving, one is able to properly embrace sentient beings.
By means of the perfection of morality, one does not harm sentient beings, because one does not give rise to afflictions.
By means of the perfection of patience, even if one is harmed, one is able to endure it. Because one is able to endure it, one is able to benefit others, because one does not retaliate.
By means of the perfection of vigor, one assists them in what they do.
By means of the perfection of meditation, one causes those whose minds are unsettled to attain concentration.
By the perfection of wisdom, those whose minds are already concentrated attain liberation.
The time of enlightenment refers to the time when they are instructed to attain realization of the object.
Those who have attained maturity refer to those who have already attained maturity in regard to the object.

As for maturity, it means that the obstacles to be eliminated have been dissolved and dispersed, like a boil that has matured, or that the antidotes have been perfected and can be used, like food that has been cooked.
The treatise states:
How can these six aspects be seen?
Because of six kinds of supremacy.
First, supremacy of basis, which means taking enlightenment mind as the basis.
Second, supremacy of practice, which means being fully engaged.

Third, supremacy of place, which means taking the welfare and happiness of all sentient beings as the basis.ğŸ”½Fourth, supremacy of skillful means, which means being embraced by non-discriminating wisdom.
Fifth, supremacy of dedication, which means dedicating [merit] to unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Sixth, it is due to the most excellent purity, because it is accumulated and produced without the obstructions of the two hindrances of afflictions and the knowable.ğŸ”½Is giving a pÄramitÄ?
If it is a pÄramitÄ, is it giving?
There are four alternatives regarding giving that is not a pÄramitÄ.
As with giving, the other pÄramitÄs should be understood in four alternatives as appropriate.
The commentary says:
Based on the established characteristics, it is said: Because of the six kinds of supremacy, etc.
The six kinds of supremacy are easily understood and do not need to be explained separately.
Because of the complete performance means because one is able to give up everything internally and externally.
Because it is embraced by non-discriminating cognition means because the three spheres are pure, and the discriminations of giver, receiver, and gift are all far removed.
The rest of the text is easy to understand.
There is giving that is not a pÄramitÄ means giving that is cultivated apart from the six kinds of supremacy.
There is that which is a pÄramitÄ but not giving, namely, the precepts and so forth collected by the six kinds of supreme [attainments].
There is that which is both giving and a pÄramitÄ, namely, the giving collected by the six kinds of supreme [attainments].
There is that which is neither giving nor a pÄramitÄ, namely, the cultivation of precepts and so forth apart from the six kinds of supreme [attainments].
Just as there are these four statements in regard to giving, so too should they be well established in regard to the other five, such as precepts, as appropriate.
Therefore, there is a verse that says:
The rhinoceros-like one has no six pÄramitÄs,
Only I, the most supreme honored one, has the highest pÄramitÄs.
The treatise says:
For what causes and conditions are these six pÄramitÄs taught in this sequence?
It is because the preceding pÄramitÄ gives rise to the subsequent pÄramitÄ.
The commentary says:

Because they conform to the subsequent perfections means that having already not been attached to wealth and status, one is able to guard morality. Having complete morality, one is then able to endure. Being able to endure, one is able to tolerate contradictions and thus gives rise to vigor. Having given rise to vigor, the mind then attains concentration. Having attained concentration, one is able to know reality as it is. Therefore, these six are in this sequence.
The treatise says:
Next, how can the etymological explanations of these perfections be seen?
They are called perfections because they are supreme among the roots of goodness such as giving in the world, among the hearers and solitary realizers, and are able to reach the other shore.
They are also called giving because they are able to break through stinginess and poverty and are able to attract vast wealth, status, and the provisions of blessings and virtues.
They are also called morality because they are able to extinguish evil conduct and evil destinies and are able to obtain good destinies and meditative absorptions.
Moreover, it can extinguish anger and enmity, and can skillfully abide in the peace and security of oneself and others, therefore it is called patience.
Moreover, it can distance oneself from all laziness and evil unwholesome dharmas, and can give rise to and increase immeasurable wholesome dharmas, therefore it is called vigor.
Moreover, it can eliminate all scattered agitation, and can attract the mind to abide inwardly, therefore it is called meditative concentration.
Moreover, it can dispel all views and wrong wisdom, and can truly discern dharmas, therefore it is called wisdom.
The explanation says:

The explanation of the general name is that among all the wholesome roots such as giving in the world, Å›rÄvakas, and pratyekabuddhas, this is the most supreme and can reach the other shore, therefore it is generally called pÄramitÄ.
The name reaching the other shore has the meaning of being most supreme.

As for the specific names, at the time of the cause one is able to destroy stinginess and is also able to attract the equipment of extensive merit and virtue, and at the time of the effect one is able to rend poverty and obtain great wealth and status. Therefore it is called giving.
The other specific names are easily understood.
The treatise says:
How should one understand the cultivation of these perfections?
It should be known that this cultivation is of five kinds:
1. Cultivation of present activity, 2. cultivation of superior understanding, 3. cultivation of attention, 4. cultivation of skillful means, and 5. cultivation of accomplishing what is to be done.
Among these, four cultivations are as explained above.

As for the cultivation of accomplishing what is to be done, it refers to the effortless buddha-work of the tathÄgatas without rest. In the perfection that is complete, they further cultivate the six perfections.

Moreover, the cultivation of mental attention refers to the cultivation of the mental attentions of fondness, delight, and joy, which are included in the six kinds of mental intentions: the intention of vastness, the intention of long duration, the intention of joy, the intention of gratitude, the intention of great aspiration, and the intention of complete goodness.

If bodhisattvas were to realize supreme perfect enlightenment in a certain number of innumerable great eons, and for that length of time in each instant were to suddenly give up all their bodies and lives, and were to offer to the TathÄgatas worlds as numerous as the sands of the Ganges filled with the seven treasures, and were to continue doing so until seated in the sublime bodhi-seat, the bodhisattvas' intention of generosity would still not be satisfied.

For that length of time, in each instant, even if the three thousand great one thousand worlds were filled with blazing fire, in the four modes of deportment one would always lack all the requisites for life, and the mind of morality, patience, vigor, meditation, and wisdom would always be in operation, up to sitting on the wondrous bodhi seat.
Thus, the bodhisattva's morality, patience, vigor, meditation, and wisdom intentions are still insatiable, which is called the bodhisattva's vast intention.
Moreover, the bodhisattvas in this [state] have an insatiable intention, up to sitting on the wondrous bodhi seat, always without interruption, which is called the bodhisattva's long-term intention.

Moreover, the bodhisattvas benefit beings with the six perfections, and because of this they deeply rejoice, which is not equaled by the benefited beings, which is called the bodhisattva's joyful intention.

Moreover, when bodhisattvas benefit sentient beings with the six perfections, they see that those beings have great kindness and virtue toward them, but they do not see themselves as having any kindness toward those beings. This is called the bodhisattvas' attitude of gratitude.

Moreover, when bodhisattvas deeply dedicate the wholesome roots they have gathered through the six perfections to all sentient beings, wishing that they may attain the most excellent and delightful karmic retribution, this is called the bodhisattvas' attitude of great aspiration.

Moreover, when bodhisattvas share the wholesome roots they have gathered through the six perfections with all sentient beings, dedicating them toward unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, this is called the bodhisattvas' attitude of pure goodness.
In this way, bodhisattvas cultivate the six attitudes that are included within the attitude of cherishing.

Moreover, when bodhisattvas deeply rejoice in the immeasurable wholesome roots associated with the six attitudes cultivated by other bodhisattvas, in this way bodhisattvas cultivate the six attitudes that are included within the attitude of rejoicing.

Moreover, bodhisattvas deeply delight in the six perfections cultivated by the six kinds of intentions of all sentient beings, and also vow that their own practice of the six perfections will always be inseparable, until they sit on the wondrous seat of enlightenment. Such is the bodhisattvas' cultivation of the intentions encompassed by the six kinds of intentions.

If there are those who, having heard of this bodhisattva's cultivation encompassed by the six kinds of intentions, are able to give rise to a single thought of faith, they will still generate immeasurable merit and destroy all evil karmic hindrances, let alone bodhisattvas.
The commentary says:
Cultivation means repeated practice.
There are five distinctions in the cultivation of manifestation, etc.
The cultivation of manifest practice means to proceed without error in giving, etc.
As a verse says:
The giver is superior, endowed with faith, etc., respectful, timely,
giving with one's own hands, and so forth.
And as a verse says:
The practice of benefiting others does not discriminate between those with power and those without power among sentient beings,
and at all times and in all ways, one gives according to one's ability and to the extent possible, extensively benefiting them.
The cultivation of resolve refers to giving rise to resolve through faith and desire, because one deeply approves of and delights in the Buddha's teachings.
As a verse says:
Although one is without effort in benefiting others, one gives rise to resolve in the Buddha's teachings,
because of being associated with faith and desire, one's intention always cultivates without slacking off.
The cultivation of attention refers to the cultivation encompassed by the attentions of cherishing, rejoicing, and delighting, as explained above.
The cultivation of skillful means refers to the cultivation encompassed by non-discriminating cognition, as explained above.

The cultivation of the performance of deeds refers to the fact that, although the dharmas of the tathÄgatas that are perfections are extremely perfect, due to the power of their original vows to benefit others, they do not exert effort but manifest the deeds that should be performed, such as giving, etc., according to the abilities of others.
This is precisely cultivation, and because it is cultivated for their sake, it is also called cultivation.

Moreover, the sound [in the verse] intends to explain the meaning of the distinction in the cultivation of mental attention that was previously mentioned, namely, the cultivation that is included in the six kinds of mental states, up to the mental states of being insatiable, etc.
The words are easy to understand, and the few places where there is little explanation.
Insatiable means being without fatigue.

For that length of time, in each instant, or some say that for that length of time is one instant, that is, for the duration of three incalculably long eons, it is one instant. Such instants accumulate up to the attainment of great enlightenment.
For that length of time, in each instant, the meaning is easy to understand.
Filled with blazing fire means manifesting a lack of superior places.
The phrase always lacking all the requisites of livelihood shows that there is no remedy for suffering, because the requisites of livelihood are accepted in order to cure suffering.
The phrase in the four postures of the body shows that the will is vast.
Even though one lacks superior states and the requisites of livelihood, in all four postures one cultivates morality, etc., and the will to attain the other shore is always present.
The phrase for a long time means for a long period without interruption.
The phrase the will to bear the burden means that one has deep faith and understanding that those who come to make requests are good friends.
This means that one has faith in those who come to make requests, that they bestow upon oneself a lovely and wonderful fruition of retribution. Therefore, one bears the burden.
The phrase the will of great aspiration means that this will is associated with great aspiration, in order to benefit all sentient beings.

One turns over one's wholesome roots and bestows them upon all. Such a will is most distinguished, and therefore it is called the will of great aspiration. The meaning of the will of pure goodness is the same.

As for establishing different names, if one uses giving and so forth to seek the three realms of existence and the perfection of wealth and status, with such an intention hoping for the means of suffering, it is similar to having faults and is not called pure good.

If one uses giving and so forth together with all sentient beings to seek the fruit of Buddhahood, with such an intention not seeking the means of suffering, it is completely without faults and is called pure good.
Cultivating these six kinds of intentions and the three kinds of attention, the words are easy to understand and there is no need for further explanation.
As for the various evil karmic hindrances also being extinguished, it means that they are without fruit, or because they treat evil destinies.
The treatise says:
How can the distinctions of these perfections be seen?
It should be known that each has three grades.
The three grades of giving are: first, the giving of Dharma, second, the giving of wealth, and third, the giving of fearlessness.
The three grades of precepts are: first, the precepts of restraining from wrongdoing, second, the precepts of accumulating good dharmas, and third, the precepts of benefiting sentient beings.
The three grades of patience are: patience in enduring harm from others, patience in accepting suffering, and patience in investigating dharmas.
The three grades of vigor are: vigor in donning armor, vigor in practice, and vigor that is not fainthearted, does not regress, and is not content with little.
The three grades of meditation are: meditation in abiding, meditation in producing, and meditation in accomplishing deeds.
The three grades of wisdom are: wisdom in the preparatory stage of non-discrimination, wisdom of non-discrimination, and wisdom subsequent to non-discrimination.
The commentary says:
By these, each of the perfections is shown to have three grades of distinctions.
As for the giving of Dharma, it means to expound the sutras and other teachings with an undefiled mind and in accordance with reality.
As for the giving of material things, it means to give away possessions with an undefiled mind.
As for the giving of fearlessness, it means to stop harm and rescue those who are frightened.
Moreover, the gift of the Dharma benefits the roots of goodness of others, the gift of wealth benefits the bodies of others, and the gift of fearlessness benefits the minds of others.

The morality of restraint means that one is able to distance oneself from dharmas that are unwholesome and to protect and uphold [wholesome dharmas]. Because one is able to protect and guard against evil and unwholesome bodily and verbal actions, it is called restraint.

This is precisely morality. This is able to establish the latter two types of morality. Because by restraining oneself one is able to cultivate the roots of goodness such as making offerings to the Buddha, and because one is able to benefit all sentient beings.
The morality of accumulating good dharmas is able to cause one to realize all the Buddha-dharmas such as the powers and fearlessnesses.

The morality of benefiting sentient beings is able to assist sentient beings in performing wholesome actions in accordance with the Dharma, distributing them equally, and engaging in activities that are free from wrongdoing, thereby bringing sentient beings to maturity.

The patience of enduring harm from others is the causal condition for bringing sentient beings to maturity. The patience of enduring suffering is the causal condition for becoming a Buddha, because one is able to endure various sufferings such as cold, heat, hunger, and thirst without turning back.
The patience of investigating dharmas is the basis of the former two patiences, because one is able to endure the profound and vast dharmas.
The armor-like effort is that which initially resolves to do such and such things. This is the explanation of the first phrase in the sutra, having power.
The effort of application is that which, at the time of application, diligently applies itself as one wishes. This is the explanation of the next phrase in the sutra, having exertion.

The effort of not being discouraged, not turning back, and not being satisfied is that which, following one's wishes, does good things until finally sitting on the wonderful terrace of enlightenment, never letting go.
The mind not retreating in one's own fatigue and suffering is called not being discouraged. The mind not moving in the oppression of others is called not turning back.
Until enlightenment, in the meantime cultivating good dharmas without ever slacking off is called not being satisfied.
These three phrases explain the sutra's phrases having courage, being firm and vigorous, and not abandoning the yoke of good dharmas in order.
Abiding meditation is for attaining the bliss of the present Dharma, in order to be free from pride, views, and craving and attain purity.
Eliciting meditation is for being able to elicit the excellent qualities such as the six supernormal powers.
Meditation for accomplishing what is to be done is for the sake of benefiting the various kinds of sentient beings, because it can stop hunger, poverty, disease, fear, and other kinds of suffering.
Non-discriminating preparatory wisdom refers to the wisdom of excellent skillful means prior to true contemplation.
Non-discriminating wisdom refers to the wisdom of true contemplation.
Non-discriminating subsequent attainment wisdom refers to the worldly wisdom at the edge of realization, which is able to give rise to various activities such as teaching the Dharma.
The treatise says:
How can this inclusion be seen?
Because it is the characteristic of being able to include all wholesome dharmas, because it is in accordance with them, and because it is their outflow.
The commentary says:
As for because it is able to include all wholesome dharmas, this answer is unreasonable because it does not correspond to the question.
The previous general question asked, How can one see such mutual inclusion?
There is no fault in saying that this includes all wholesome dharmas, as the meaning has already been explained.
They also include all these wholesome dharmas refers to giving, faith, mindfulness, powers, etc.
Because they are its characteristics means the essence of inclusion is that these dharmas of giving, etc. mutually include each other.

Because they are its concomitants means the inclusion of concomitants, i.e., faith, etc., wholesome dharmas, because the wholesome mind of giving, etc. cultivates them, and because they accompany giving, etc.
Faith, etc. are the great giving of all wholesome dharmas, the factors of enlightenment such as mindfulness, etc.
Because they are its outflow means the inclusion of outflow, i.e., the absence of conflict, etc., and the ten powers, etc., because they are the outflow effect of the perfections, etc.
As a verse says:
The stages and perfections, the basis of the Buddhadharmas,
The results are the qualities such as the Dharma body of the transformation of the basis.
The treatise says:
How can it be seen that the objects of abandonment include all defilements?
Because they are its characteristics, because they are its causes, and because they are its results.
The commentary says:
How can these objects of abandonment, stinginess, immorality, anger, laziness, distraction, and false wisdom, include all defilements?
Because they are its characteristics means that they include the specific natures of stinginess, etc., apart from other natures.
Because they are its causes means that lack of faith, etc., and wrong views are the causes of stinginess, etc., in the end.
The treatise says:
How can the benefits obtained from these six perfections be seen?

That is, because bodhisattvas transmigrate through saá¹ƒsÄra, they are included in the wealthy and noble, included in the great births, included in the great retinue and great dependents, included in the accomplishment of vast and great activities, included in the absence of various afflictions and the thin dust of defilements, and included in the knowledge of all the sciences and treatises. From the superior birth without fault up to sitting on the wonderful seat of enlightenment, they are always able to manifest and accomplish all the benefits of all beings. This is called the benefit.
The commentary says:
Now we will clearly explain the merits and virtues of the perfections.
Because of being included in the wealthy and noble is the benefit obtained from the perfection of giving.
From the superior birth without fault up to this is called the benefit should be applied everywhere.
Because of being included in the great births is the benefit obtained from the perfection of morality. Because it includes the superior destinies, it is called the great births.
Because it is embraced by a great retinue and a great following refers to the benefits obtained from the perfection of patience.
Retinue refers to relatives, and following refers to servants.
Because it is embraced by the accomplishment of vast activities and practices refers to the benefits obtained from the perfection of vigor.
Vast activities refers to those of a wheel-turning king and so forth.
Practice refers to the exertion in these activities, and accomplishment means the completion of what is to be done. Because of this, there is nothing that is obstructed.

Because it is embraced by the absence of all harm and the thinness of defilements refers to the benefits obtained from the perfection of meditation, because through meditation one gives rise to this power.
Because it is embraced by the knowledge of all the sciences and treatises refers to the benefits obtained from the perfection of wisdom.
Superior rebirth without fault means that although one attains the most superior rebirth in the world, it is unlike the superior rebirth of the world which has faults.

Since there are no faults, and time is boundless and uninterrupted, continuing until enlightenment, it is not like in the world where one only benefits oneself. It is always able to manifest and accomplish all the benefits of all sentient beings.
The treatise states:
How can these six kinds of pÄramitÄs be mutually determined?

The World-Honored One, in regard to these six pÄramitÄs, sometimes uses the term giving, sometimes the term precepts, sometimes the term patience, sometimes the term diligence, sometimes the term concentration, and sometimes the term wisdom. What is the meaning of these teachings?
It means that in the practice of all pÄramitÄs, all pÄramitÄs mutually assist each other.
This is the meaning.
